name: copper production, cathode, solvent extraction and electrowinning process | copper, cathode | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/21253/documentation

Mining process, starting from copper ore, in ground.

This dataset ends with the refining of copper.

The dataset includes the grounding of the ore, the gravity concentration of the ore, the pretreatment of the ore prior to hydrometallurgy, the dump leaching step for copper recovery, the solution cleaning step, and the separation step. Also included are the disposal of overburden & tailings, and the Production infrastructure used directly for mining.
category: C:Manufacturing/24:Manufacture of basic metals/242:Manufacture of basic precious and other non-ferrous metals/2420:Manufacture of basic precious and other non-ferrous metals

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This module is valid for an average world-wide process.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Oxide ores and supergene sulphide ores (i.e. ores not containing iron) can be recovered most easily by hydro-metallurgical techniques, such as SX-EW. The general steps of mining and refining are identical to those of copper mine operation and primary copper production, respectively. The difference lies in that the beneficiation and smelting stages are by-passed and substituted with a leaching stage followed by cementation or electro-winning.

exchanges.description:
Before end-use copper is manufactured into semi fabricated products, such as shapes and ingots (known as “semis”). These manufacturing processes are subdivided into hot working, cold working and, if necessary, process annealing.

Few of the semis are ready for use as such. They more typically travel to first-stage manufacturers, who make metal rods, wire, and casting, and then to component manufacturers who produce such things as motors, valves, and insulated cables 
The components in turn are incorporated by final-stage manufacturers into a variety of finished products - automobiles, commercial buildings, residential housing, and so forth. These uses account for about 79% of the world-wide consumption of copper.

Literature value.
